title: South Indian Cultural Sites Tour
description: A guided tour of famous cultural sites in South India
author: Cultural Explorer

slides.title: Meenakshi Amman Temple
slides.subtitle: Madurai, Tamil Nadu
slides.description: The Meenakshi Amman Temple is dedicated to goddess Meenakshi (a form of Parvati) and her consort, Sundareshwar (a form of Shiva). This magnificent site is known for its towering gopurams (gateway towers) adorned with thousands of colorful sculptures.
keyFacts: Features 14 gateway towers ranging from 45-50 meters in height
The complex covers 45 acres
Has a sacred tank called the Golden Lotus Tank (Porthamarai Kulam)
The current structure dates mainly to the 16th-17th centuries

slides.title: Brihadeeswarar Temple
slides.subtitle: Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu
slides.description: Also known as Peruvudaiyar Kovil, this site is dedicated to Lord Shiva and was built by Raja Raja Chola I in the 11th century. It's a UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the largest monuments in India.
keyFacts: The main vimana (tower) stands at 216 feet (66 meters) tall
Built entirely of granite with over 130,000 tons of granite used
The main lingam is one of the largest in India, standing about 3.7 meters tall
The structure's shadow never falls on the ground at noon

slides.title: Virupaksha Temple
slides.subtitle: Hampi, Karnataka
slides.description: Dedicated to Lord Virupaksha, a form of Shiva, this is the oldest and principal monument in Hampi. The site continues to prosper as an important pilgrimage center even after the fall of the Vijayanagara Empire.
keyFacts: History dates back to the 7th century
The main gopuram stands 50 meters high
Features exquisite stone carvings and impressive pillared halls
Houses the shrine of Pampa, the local river goddess and consort of Virupaksha

slides.title: Ekambareswarar Temple
slides.subtitle: Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu
slides.description: This site is dedicated to Shiva as Ekambareswarar (Lord of the Single Mango Tree). It is one of the Pancha Bhoota Stalas representing the element Earth and is known for its 3,500-year-old mango tree.
keyFacts: Features a 59-meter high gopuram, one of the tallest towers in South India
The complex covers 23 acres
Contains 1,000 lingam sculptures
The legendary mango tree is said to produce four different types of mangoes

slides.title: Annamalaiyar Temple
slides.subtitle: Tiruvannamalai, Tamil Nadu
slides.description: Dedicated to Lord Shiva, this site represents the element fire among the Pancha Bhoota Stalas. The monument is associated with the sacred hill Arunachala, which is considered a manifestation of Shiva himself.
keyFacts: The main gopuram is 217 feet (66 meters) high
The complex spans 25 acres
During the Karthigai Deepam festival, a huge lamp is lit atop the Arunachala Hill
The site has been praised in the Tamil Tevaram hymns by saints Sambandar and Appar

slides.title: Ramanathaswamy Temple
slides.subtitle: Rameswaram, Tamil Nadu
slides.description: This monument is dedicated to Lord Shiva and is significant as one of the twelve Jyotirlinga shrines. According to legend, Lord Rama worshipped Shiva here to cleanse himself of the sin of killing Ravana.
keyFacts: Features the longest corridor among all Hindu sites, with 1,212 pillars
Has 22 theerthams (holy water tanks) within the complex
The main shrine houses a lingam that was installed by Lord Rama himself
The design follows Dravidian architecture with massive walls and gopurams

slides.title: Padmanabhaswamy Temple
slides.subtitle: Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala
slides.description: This monument is dedicated to Lord Vishnu in the form of Padmanabha (one who emerges from the lotus) reclining on the serpent Anantha. The site gained international attention for its vast treasure discovered in sealed vaults.
keyFacts: The main deity is a 18-foot-long Vishnu in Anantha Shayanam posture
Built in a blend of Kerala and Dravidian architectural styles
It's one of the 108 sacred Vishnu sites or Divya Desams
The monument was controlled by the royal family of Travancore until recent times
